wiki_catalogs.name: Project Overview
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for the project overview focused on RAGFlow. Explain its purpose as an open-source Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) engine that combines advanced RAG capabilities with Agent functionality to create a superior context layer for Large Language Models (LLMs). Describe how it transforms complex data into high-fidelity, production-ready AI systems. Cover the main components including document processing, agent system, search and retrieval, and user interface. Explain the relationship between the frontend (web/) and backend (api/) components. Include both conceptual overviews for beginners and technical details for experienced developers. Provide practical examples of common use cases such as document processing, knowledge extraction, AI-powered search, and automated data analysis. Document the implementation details, architecture, and usage patterns using terminology consistent with the codebase.

wiki_catalogs.name: Document Processing
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the document processing feature of RAGFlow. Thoroughly explain the implementation of deep document understanding with specialized parsers for various formats including PDF, DOCX, PPT, Excel, HTML, and JSON. Document the template-based intelligent chunking strategies including token-based and title-based segmentation. Explain the automated RAG workflow orchestration and heterogeneous data source compatibility. Include concrete examples from the actual codebase showing how documents are processed through the pipeline. Document configuration options in the parsing and chunking forms, parameters for different document types, and return values. Address common issues like parsing errors and their solutions. Make content accessible to beginners while providing sufficient technical depth for experienced developers on the document processing architecture.

wiki_catalogs.name: Frontend Architecture
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for RAGFlow's frontend architecture. Describe the high-level design using React with the Umi framework, Ant Design components, and Tailwind CSS for styling. Document the component-based architecture, state management patterns, and routing system. Explain the integration with backend services through REST APIs and WebSocket connections. Include details on the UI component library, theming system, and internationalization support. Address performance optimization techniques, accessibility compliance, and responsive design patterns. Document the build process, development server configuration, and deployment workflow. Provide insights into the folder structure organization and code splitting strategy.

wiki_catalogs.name: Docker Compose Deployment
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for Docker Compose deployment focused on RAGFlow. Provide step-by-step instructions for setting up RAGFlow using Docker Compose, starting with environment preparation and prerequisite installation (Docker, Docker Compose). Detail the configuration of environment variables in the .env file and service_conf.yaml.template. Explain the purpose and usage of each docker-compose file variant (base, macos, CN-oc9) for different deployment scenarios. Include practical examples of startup commands, network configuration, and volume mounting. Document the service dependencies and startup order. Address common issues such as port conflicts, resource limitations, and container health checks. Provide guidance on post-deployment verification, including accessing the web interface and testing API connectivity. Include best practices for production deployment, such as resource allocation, persistent storage, and security considerations.

wiki_catalogs.name: HTTP API Reference
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive HTTP API documentation for RAGFlow. Document all endpoints in the api/apps/ directory, including their HTTP methods, URL patterns, request/response schemas, authentication methods, and error handling. For each endpoint group (e.g., knowledge base, document, chunk, chat, agent, user management), provide detailed descriptions of functionality, parameters, request body structures, and response formats. Include authentication mechanisms using OAuth, OIDC, and GitHub integration. Document rate limiting, versioning, and security considerations. Provide practical examples for common operations such as creating knowledge bases, uploading documents, querying data, managing agents, and handling conversations. Address error codes, debugging strategies, and performance optimization tips. Include client implementation guidelines and monitoring approaches for production use.

Include guidance on how the configuration interacts with the settings.py file for environment-specific overrides. Detail the implementation of code_exec.py and its integration with the sandbox environment for secure code execution. Explain the security model, including containerization, resource limits, and restricted execution environments. Document supported programming languages, execution parameters, and timeout configurations. Provide examples of executing Python and other code snippets within agent workflows. Cover error handling for compilation and runtime errors, output capturing, and security considerations for executing untrusted code. Include best practices for input validation and preventing code injection attacks.

wiki_catalogs.name: Title-Based Chunking
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the title-based chunking feature of RAGFlow. Thoroughly explain the implementation of title-based segmentation that uses table of contents detection and extraction to create semantically meaningful chunks. Document how the system employs LLM prompts (toc_detection.md, toc_extraction.md, assign_toc_levels.md) to identify document structure and hierarchy. Include concrete examples from splitter.py showing how the TitleSplitter class processes documents with clear section headings. Explain the configuration options for title extraction and level assignment, and their impact on chunk quality. Address common issues like missing or inconsistent headings and their solutions. Make content accessible to beginners while providing sufficient technical depth for experienced developers on the title detection algorithms and their impact on retrieval quality.

wiki_catalogs.name: DOCX Document Parsing
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the DOCX document parsing capability in RAGFlow. Thoroughly explain the implementation of the DOCX parser, including how it extracts text, preserves document structure, and handles formatting elements like headings, lists, tables, and images. Document the handling of complex DOCX features such as embedded objects, comments, and track changes. Explain the configuration options for DOCX parsing, such as managing large documents, preserving styles, and handling password-protected files. Include concrete examples from the codebase showing how DOCX content is processed through the parsing pipeline. Address common issues like corrupted DOCX files, compatibility with different Word versions, and formatting inconsistencies, along with their solutions. Make content accessible to beginners while providing sufficient technical depth for experienced developers on the DOCX parsing architecture.

wiki_catalogs.name: Vector Similarity Search
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the vector similarity search recall method in RAGFlow. Explain the implementation of embedding-based retrieval using cosine similarity and other distance metrics, including how document and query embeddings are generated and compared. Document the One retrieval application's architecture and its integration with the extractor module for creating vector representations. Include concrete examples from the codebase showing configuration of vector search parameters like similarity thresholds, top-k results, and hybrid scoring. Explain the domain model for vector-based retrieval, including index types (e.g., HNSW, IVF) and their performance characteristics. Address common issues such as the curse of dimensionality, cold start problems, and maintaining embedding model consistency, along with solutions like reindexing strategies and embedding quality monitoring. Provide guidance on optimizing vector search performance through index tuning and hardware acceleration.

wiki_catalogs.name: Entity Extraction
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the entity extraction feature in RAGFlow's knowledge graph integration. Thoroughly explain the implementation of named entity recognition, entity linking, and entity resolution processes. Document the interfaces and usage patterns of the graph_extractor and entity_resolution components, including their domain models and invocation relationships. Include concrete examples from the actual codebase showing how entities are extracted from text, disambiguated, and merged across documents. Document configuration options for extraction thresholds, resolution similarity metrics, and return values. Address common issues like entity ambiguity and cross-document coreference, and their solutions. Make content accessible to beginners while providing sufficient technical depth for experienced developers on the entity extraction pipeline.

wiki_overview.content:
<blog>
# Comprehensive Project Analysis: RAGFlow

## 1. Project Introduction

### Purpose Statement
RAGFlow is an open-source Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) engine that combines advanced RAG capabilities with Agent functionality to create a superior context layer for Large Language Models (LLMs). The project aims to transform complex data into high-fidelity, production-ready AI systems with exceptional efficiency and precision.

### Core Goals and Objectives
- Provide a streamlined RAG workflow adaptable to enterprises of any scale
- Offer deep document understanding for knowledge extraction from unstructured data
- Enable template-based chunking with intelligent and explainable methods
- Support grounded citations with reduced hallucinations through visualization
- Ensure compatibility with heterogeneous data sources including Word, slides, Excel, images, and web pages
- Automate and simplify the RAG workflow for both personal and large business use

### Target Audience
- Enterprise developers and data scientists
- AI/ML engineers building RAG-based applications
- Organizations seeking to implement AI-powered document processing and knowledge management
- Developers looking for a comprehensive RAG solution with agent capabilities

## 2. Technical Architecture

### Component Breakdown
RAGFlow follows a modular architecture with distinct components:

```mermaid
flowchart TD
    A[Frontend] --> B[API Layer]
    B --> C[Business Logic]
    C --> D[Data Access]
    D --> E[(Database)]
    C --> F[Document Store]
    C --> G[Storage]
    C --> H[LLM Integration]
    I[Agent System] --> C
    J[Data Connectors] --> C
    K[Sandbox] --> C
```

### Design Patterns
The project implements several key design patterns:

1. **Service Pattern**: Database operations are encapsulated in service classes that extend a CommonService base class, providing consistent CRUD operations.
2. **Dependency Injection**: Configuration and services are initialized at startup and injected into components.
3. **Event-Driven Architecture**: Task processing uses a message queue (Redis) for asynchronous document processing.
4. **Factory Pattern**: Storage implementations are created through a StorageFactory based on configuration.
5. **Singleton Pattern**: Database connection is managed as a singleton instance.

### System Relationships
The architecture consists of several interconnected systems:

```mermaid
graph TD
    Web[Web Frontend] --> API[API Server]
    API --> DB[MySQL Database]
    API --> ES[Elasticsearch/Infinity]
    API --> Redis[Redis Message Queue]
    API --> MinIO[MinIO Storage]
    API --> LLM[LLM Services]
    TaskExecutor[Sandbox Task Executor] --> Redis
    TaskExecutor --> MinIO
    TaskExecutor --> LLM
```

### Data Flow
The data processing flow follows this pattern:

```mermaid
flowchart TD
    A[User Uploads Document] --> B[API Receives Request]
    B --> C[Store in MinIO]
    C --> D[Create Processing Task]
    D --> E[Queue in Redis]
    E --> F[Task Executor Processes]
    F --> G[Extract Text/Chunks]
    G --> H[Store Chunks in Elasticsearch/Infinity]
    H --> I[Generate Embeddings]
    I --> J[Store in Vector Database]
    J --> K[Ready for Retrieval]
```

## 3. Key Implementation

### Main Entry Points
- `api/ragflow_server.py` - Main server entry point that initializes the application
- `web/src` - Frontend application source code
- `agent/component/` - Agent system components
- `rag/flow/` - RAG pipeline components

### Core Modules
- **API Layer**: `api/apps/` - Flask-based API endpoints for various services
- **Database Services**: `api/db/services/` - Service classes for database operations
- **Document Processing**: `deepdoc/parser/` - Document parsing and text extraction
- **RAG Pipeline**: `rag/flow/` - Components for document processing pipeline
- **Agent System**: `agent/component/` - Agent with tools and workflow components
- **Data Connectors**: `common/data_source/` - Connectors for various data sources

### Configuration Approach
The project uses a hierarchical configuration system:

```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Environment Variables] --> B[service_conf.yaml]
    B --> C[settings.py]
    C --> D[Runtime Configuration]
    E[conf/] --> B
    F[docker/.env] --> A
```

Key configuration files:
- `conf/service_conf.yaml` - Main service configuration
- `docker/.env` - Environment variables for Docker deployment
- `common/settings.py` - Runtime settings management
- `conf/llm_factories.json` - LLM provider configurations

### External Dependencies
- **Database**: MySQL, Redis
- **Document Storage**: Elasticsearch, Infinity, OceanBase
- **Object Storage**: MinIO, AWS S3, Azure Blob, Alibaba OSS
- **LLM Providers**: OpenAI, Anthropic, Google, Baidu, etc.
- **Processing**: PyTorch, Transformers, various document parsing libraries

### Integration Points
- **Authentication**: GitHub OAuth, Feishu OAuth, custom authentication
- **Data Sources**: Google Drive, Jira, Confluence, Notion, Discord, Slack, Teams
- **Extensions**: Chrome extension, WeChat plugin
- **External Services**: Firecrawl web scraping integration
- **Monitoring**: Langfuse integration for tracing

### Component Relationships
```mermaid
graph LR
    A[API Server] --> B[Database Services]
    A --> C[Document Store]
    A --> D[Storage]
    A --> E[LLM]
    B --> F[User Service]
    B --> G[Knowledgebase Service]
    B --> H[Document Service]
    B --> I[Task Service]
    C --> J[Document Processing]
    D --> K[File Storage]
    E --> L[Chat Models]
    E --> M[Embedding Models]
    E --> N[Rerank Models]
    J --> O[DeepDoc Parser]
    P[Agent System] --> Q[Tool Integration]
    Q --> R[Web Search]
    Q --> S[Code Execution]
    Q --> T[Database Query]
```

## 4. Key Features

### Functionality Overview
RAGFlow provides a comprehensive set of features for building RAG-based applications:

```mermaid
stateDiagram-v2
    [*] --> DocumentUpload
    DocumentUpload --> DocumentProcessing: Upload
    DocumentProcessing --> Chunking: Parse
    Chunking --> Embedding: Split
    Embedding --> VectorStorage: Generate
    VectorStorage --> ReadyForQuery: Store
    ReadyForQuery --> QueryProcessing: Receive Query
    QueryProcessing --> Retrieval: Search
    Retrieval --> Generation: Combine
    Generation --> Response: Answer
    Response --> ReadyForQuery: Loop
```

### Implementation Highlights
- **Deep Document Understanding**: Uses specialized parsers for different document types (PDF, Word, Excel, etc.)
- **Template-based Chunking**: Multiple chunking strategies available through configurable templates
- **Grounded Citations**: Visualizes text chunking and provides traceable citations
- **Heterogeneous Data Support**: Handles various file formats and data sources
- **Automated RAG Workflow**: Streamlined orchestration with configurable LLMs and embedding models
- **Multiple Recall with Fused Re-ranking**: Combines multiple retrieval methods with re-ranking

### Feature Architecture
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Document Ingestion] --> B[Content Extraction]
    B --> C[Text Processing]
    C --> D[Chunking Strategies]
    D --> E[Embedding Generation]
    E --> F[Vector Storage]
    F --> G[Query Processing]
    G --> H[Retrieval Methods]
    H --> I[Reranking]
    I --> J[Response Generation]
    J --> K[Citation Linking]
    K --> L[Answer Delivery]
    M[Agent System] --> N[Tool Selection]
    N --> O[Action Execution]
    O --> P[Result Aggregation]
    P --> J
```
